text: Such an ekphrastic title is borrowed from Modest Mussorgsky's famous suite of ten piano pieces, composed in 1874. If Mussorgsky's work intertwines music and pictorial art, in these chapters we see how visual art enters the written dimension of literature. Listen to a recording [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O31KPk5xnBg).
Rime ice. Frozen water droplets. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/8b/Rime_ice.jpg)

The use of infinitives is typical of Yakov's chapters. They grant the chapters in which he features a timeless quality. On a related note, Richard Borden claims that "*Between Dog and Wolf* takes place in a circumambient projection of its author's linguistic consciousness and imagination and that claims for the existence of any more conventional setting would be misleading" ("Toward" 321).
Chickens. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/ce/Des_Poulets_Goliath_de_couleur_beige_dans_un_poulailler_au_B%C3%A9nin.jpg) Animal motif.

text: The water reservoir is first mentioned in chapter 2 (R159/E18). There, Ostanin identifies this dam and reservoir as the Ivankovo Reservoir, also known as the Moscow Sea (24). Located on the northern Volga, in the Moscow and Tver Oblasts, approximately 81 miles (130 km) north of Moscow. text: In folkloric tales, the "kostliavaia" (literally, extremely thin, bony) is the incarnation of death, an allegorical figure, usually depicted as a skeleton wearing a long black cloak (or white shroud) with a scythe. Death motif.

Sisyphus — king of Ephyra (Corinth). According to Greek mythology, Sisyphus is punished by Hades, god of the underworld, for defying death by being compelled to roll a large boulder up a hill only for it to roll down once he nears the top for eternity. Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/43/Punishment_sisyph.jpg)

text: A reference to a letter from Gustav Flaubert to Ivan Turgenev in which the former wrote: "I have always tried to live in an ivory tower, but a tide of shit is beating at its walls to undermine it" (**EXPAND: ADD CITATION**). This phrase and idea—a separation of art from worldly cares—has been widely used by many writers. It originates from [Song of Songs 7:4](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Song%20of%20Songs%207%3A4&version=NIV).

Gustav Flaubert (1821—1880), French realist novelist. Best known for *Madame Bovary*. Read it [here]((https://www.gutenberg.org/files/2413/2413-h/2413-h.htm). Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4f/Gustave_Flaubert.jpg)

The Leaning Tower of Pisa (completed 1372), which leans at four degrees.  Part of Pisa's Cathedral Square (Piazza del Duomo). Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4b/Italy_-_Pisa_-_Leaning_Tower.jpg)
prefix: е, в башне господина Флобера, в

text:
Baobab tree. Found in Africa and the Arabian Peninsula. 
Peninsula (Yemen, Oman). The *boab* tree is found in Australia. Can live to be over two thousand years old. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/09/Baobab_and_elephant%2C_Tanzania.jpg) Plant motif.
Koala. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/49/Koala_climbing_tree.jpg) Animal motif.
Set expression: usually "vniz golovoi" (upside down).

An [area](https://www.google.com/maps?q=%D1%82%D1%83%D1%88%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%BE&um=1&ie=UTF-8&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwip_LqZ8bb8AhWfM1kFHURuCqUQ_AUoAXoECAEQAw) in north Moscow, formerly a separate town. Most famous as the location occupied by False Dmitry II during the Time of Troubles.

A reference to False Dmitry I, the first of several pretenders to the Russian throne who claimed to be tsarevich Dmitry Ivanovich, son of Ivan the Terrible. After coming to power through military force and ruling from 1605 to 1606, he was killed, and his body was torn apart and burned. The remains were then shot from a cannon toward Poland. Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/41/Dymitr_Samozwaniec.jpg)

[Tula](https://www.google.com/maps/place/Tula,+Tula+Oblast,+Russia/@54.1847118,37.3568759,11z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m5!3m4!1s0x41343f84ed31c1fd:0xa3a7e25d4ca39145!8m2!3d54.204836!4d37.6184915) — the largest city in the Tula Oblast. Located south of Moscow. Known for, among other things, samovar production. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f0/Metallistov_Street_%28Tula%29.jpg)
According to Ostanin, a weapons factory has existed in Tula since 1712 (94). Sokolov adds that 200 years later his grandfather worked as the chief engineer there ("Bol'shoe pis'mo" 136).

Getting rid of her, or abusing?Is he just moving her along? Getting rid of her?It can also be used as a metaphor for a frail-looking woman. Still, I am not sure I understand what is he doing with her... and that "overtime" suggests it is something related to a work activity!

*Schlagbaum* (German: slamming down + pole). A pole or bar used to control access to a space. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4f/Moderne_Schranke.jpg?uselang=ru)

Originally referred to a military fort. With the Russian expansion into Siberia and the use of exile as a punishment, ostrogs became closely associated with imprisonment and synonymous with jails. text: Dialectical: slob. As this [blog post](https://anle-mezdu.livejournal.com/23974.html) shows, Sokolov drew many words and combinations from Dal''s dictionary, including  нехалява and нехолюза below (sensuobsceno). An early review of the novel by Igor Burikhin drew this comparison as well: "[Sokolov's language] can be compared to Dal''s dictionary heard from the gateway, at the historical and metaphysical crossroads of Russia today" (273).
Dated: weak-minded person, dotard. From the French *ramolli* (soft).

Cuffs, a layer of fabric at the lower edge of the sleeve (in Russian from the French manchette). Clothing motif.
Underwear. Clothing motif.

Dialectical: slob. As this [blog post](https://anle-mezdu.livejournal.com/23974.html) shows, Sokolov drew many words and combinations from Dal''s dictionary, including   нехолюза and нехалява above (sensuobsceno). An early review of the novel by Igor Burikhin drew this comparison as well: "[Sokolov's language] can be compared to Dal''s dictionary heard from the gateway, at the historical and metaphysical crossroads of Russia today" (273).

Diminutive of kolob, small, round bread, or dumpling of unleavened dough. Kolobok is a character in East Slavic folk tales, depicted as a small spherical-shaped wheat bread, which escaped from its baking grandparents, and later on from various animals (rabbit, wolf and bear), but was eaten in the end by a fox.

text: Yakov once worked as a courier but is now a whipper-in. There is another linguistic layer here based on the use of motion verbs "raz''ezzhat'" and "doezzhat'": he once used to travel all the time to various places (raz-), but in the end he reached a final destination (do-).

text: Ideographic writing, commonly associated with Ancient Egypt. Pictured here: [](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/25/Egypt_Hieroglyphe4.jpg)
Low: full, packed with people.

The description of train passengers is a typical subject in Russian literature. See for example Zoshchenko's short story entitled "Priiatnaia vstrecha" (1930): read the original [here](https://zoschenko.ru/cat/207/69.html). Another narrative example very close to Sokolov's is contained in Venedikt Yerofeyev's "From Moscow to Petushki", a novel written in the same years as "Between Dog and Wolf." Read the passage [here](http://kirovsk.narod.ru/culture/ludi/erofeev/proizved/petuski/8.html) (in Russian).
Set expression: as ill luck would have it.
Varied use of the expression "from the point of view": from the point of "a frowned" view.

Archaeopteryx — a genus of bird-like dinosaurs. The term comes from the ancient Greek: ἀρχαῖος ("ancient") + πτέρυξ ("feather" or "wing"). Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a4/Archaeopteryx-model.jpg?uselang=ru) Animal motif.
suffix: и которыми так и тычут друг дру

highlighted: на остановке Театр провинциалы после премьеры, открывшей очередной эзопов сезон
text: According to Ostanin, this most likely refers to the Contemporary and Taganka Theatres, located in Moscow (95). Sokolov counters: "About all theatres" ("Bol'shoe pis'mo" 137).

Aesop — the famous Greek fabulist known for his animal stories. Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a7/Vel%C3%A1zquez_-_Esopo_%28Museo_del_Prado%2C_1639-41%29.jpg?uselang=ru) Read *Aesop's Fables* [here](https://read.gov/aesop/001.html). The reference also calls to mind "Aesopian language," which, drawing back to Aesop's fables, is a means of encoding a message into an otherwise seemingly innocent story. For a consideration of Sokolov's use of aesopian language in his first novel, *A School for Fools*, see Litus 1997.
Crickets. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/10/Gryllus_campestris_MHNT.jpg) Patagonian camel crickets are mentioned throughout chapter 5. Animal motif.
Dialectical: same as мгла (haze, fog).

text: At the hour between dog and wolf.

The entire ending passage of this chapter intertwines a series of allusions to Fyodor Tiutchev's 1833 poem "Silentium": "Молчи, скрывайся и таи" (here "Прячешь, скрываешь, таишь"), the reference to silent stars in the sky, "Любуйся" (here "Радуйся"), "Их оглушит наружный шум" (here "все-то небо оглашаешь ты кликушеским балабала́"), "Внимай их пенью" (here "внемлют сему ответу"). Read the original and an English translation [here](http://max.mmlc.northwestern.edu/mdenner/Demo/texts/silentium.html).
suffix: , а если спросить отчего — не от

text: Set expression: and that's that.
A neologism meaning "having moved away from youth".
A possible reference to the moon? Here and later in on in this final passage of the chapter.

highlighted: Гори для Якова, гори для всякого
text: As in ch. 2, a reference to the saying "Икота, икота, уйди на Федота, с Федота на Якова, с Якова на всякого" (Hiccups, hiccups, go to Fedot, from Fedot to Yakov, from Yakov to everyone). This proverb derives from the folk belief that hiccups (a disease or demonic invasion) could be passed from one person to another. This hiccup (and the barrel further below) develops also the recurrent drinking theme.

highlighted:
От Георгия до Покрова, от рекостава до рекоплава и от 
черного поля до белых, осеняющих осень путей — гори вселетье
text: As this [blog post](https://anle-mezdu.livejournal.com/23974.html) shows, Sokolov drew many words and combinations from Dal''s dictionary, including those found in this sentence (sensuobsceno). An early review of the novel by Igor Burikhin drew this comparison as well: "[Sokolov's language] can be compared to Dal''s dictionary heard from the gateway, at the historical and metaphysical crossroads of Russia today" (273).

Saint George. His saint's day is April 23 Old Style / May 6 New Style. Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d5/%D0%A7%D1%83%D0%B4%D0%BE-%D0%93%D0%B5%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%B8%D1%8F-%D0%BE-%D0%97%D0%BC%D0%B8%D0%B5-%28%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B0%29.jpg?uselang=ru) Known for the legend of Saint George and the Dragon. Read a version of the tale ![here](https://americanliterature.com/childrens-stories/st-george-and-the-dragon).
